verses.text: After the king had settled in his house, and the LORD had given him rest from all his enemies around him,
verses.comment: The construction 'rest from all his enemies' is a literal translation from the Hebrew phrase (מִכָּל־אֹיְבָיו מִסָּבִיב).

verses.text: the king said to Nathan the prophet, "See now, I am living in a house of cedar, but the ark of God dwells inside a tent of curtains."
verses.comment: Translated 'tent of curtains' as literal; could also be 'tent cloth', but maintained the traditional phrase.

verses.text: Nathan said to the king, "Go, do all that is in your heart, for the LORD is with you."
verses.comment: The phrase 'do all that is in your heart' follows the Hebrew idiom, meaning 'do as you desire'.

verses.text: But that night the word of the LORD came to Nathan, saying,
verses.comment: 'word of the LORD came' is kept literal from Hebrew expression.

verses.text: "Go and say to My servant David, 'Thus says the LORD: Would you build Me a house to dwell in?
verses.comment: Quoted direct speech as in the original; 'Would you build Me a house' is a direct rendering.

verses.text: For I have not lived in a house from the day I brought up the children of Israel from Egypt to this day, but I have moved about in a tent and in a tabernacle.
verses.comment: Maintained terms 'tent' and 'tabernacle' for accuracy; Hebrew verbs translate 'moved about.'

verses.text: In all the places where I have moved with all the children of Israel, did I ever speak a word with any of the tribes of Israel, whom I commanded to shepherd My people Israel, saying, "Why have you not built Me a house of cedar?"
verses.comment: Rendered as a rhetorical question, mirroring the Hebrew structure.

verses.text: Now therefore, say this to My servant David: 'Thus says the LORD of hosts, I took you from the pasture, from following the sheep, to be ruler over My people Israel.
verses.comment: 'From the pasture, from following the sheep' translates literally; 'ruler' is often 'prince' in some translations.

verses.text: And I have been with you wherever you went and have cut off all your enemies from before you. I will make your name great, like the names of the great men of the earth.
verses.comment: The promise 'make your name great' is parallel to Gen. 12:2.

verses.text: And I will appoint a place for My people Israel and will plant them, so that they may live in their own place and not be disturbed anymore. Wicked men will not oppress them again as they did at the beginning,
verses.comment: 'I will plant them' is a metaphor from the Hebrew. 'Wicked men' translated from 'sons of wickedness.'

verses.text: even from the time that I appointed judges over My people Israel. And I will give you rest from all your enemies. Moreover, the LORD declares to you that the LORD will make a house for you.
verses.comment: 'Make a house' refers to a dynasty; kept 'house' to be faithful.

verses.text: "When your days are fulfilled and you rest with your fathers, I will raise up your offspring after you, who will come from your own body, and I will establish his kingdom.
verses.comment: 'Rest with your fathers' is a literal Hebrew idiom meaning 'die.'

verses.text: He will build a house for My name, and I will establish the throne of his kingdom forever.
verses.comment: 'House for My name' is a Hebraism indicating the temple.

verses.text: I will be his father, and he will be My son. If he commits iniquity, I will discipline him with the rod of men and with the stripes of the sons of men.
verses.comment: 'With the rod of men' and 'stripes of men' are literal renderings; discipline/punishment for sin.

verses.text: But My faithful love will not depart from him, as I took it from Saul, whom I removed from before you.
verses.comment: 'Faithful love' translates Hebrew 'chesed'; 'removed from before you' is literal.

verses.text: Your house and your kingdom will be made sure forever before Me; your throne will be established forever.'"
verses.comment: 'Made sure forever before Me' is literal, expressing permanence.

verses.text: Nathan spoke to David all these words and this entire vision.
verses.comment: Maintained the phrase 'this entire vision' as in the Hebrew.

verses.text: Then King David went in and sat before the LORD and said, "Who am I, Lord GOD, and what is my house, that You have brought me this far?
verses.comment: Direct speech is rendered in quotation marks; 'sat before the LORD' is a literal translation.

verses.text: And as if this were not enough in Your sight, Lord GOD, You have also spoken of Your servant’s house for a great while to come. And this is instruction for mankind, O Lord GOD!
verses.comment: The phrase 'instruction for mankind' is literally 'Torah for man'; some translations say 'a law for mankind'.

verses.text: What more can David say to You? For You know Your servant, Lord GOD.
verses.comment: 'For You know Your servant' rendered literally from Hebrew.

verses.text: Because of Your word and according to Your own heart, You have done all this greatness, to make Your servant know it.
verses.comment: 'According to Your own heart' mirrors the Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: Therefore You are great, O LORD God. For there is none like You, and there is no God but You, as we have heard with our ears.
verses.comment: Faithful rendering of Hebrew superlatives.

verses.text: And who is like Your people Israel, the one nation on earth whom God went to redeem for Himself as a people, to make a name for Himself and to do for them great and awesome things by driving out nations and their gods before Your people, whom You redeemed from Egypt?
verses.comment: 'Nations and their gods' is a literal rendering; 'redeem' kept for theological accuracy.

verses.text: And You established Your people Israel for Yourself as a people forever. And You, LORD, became their God.
verses.comment: Phrase structure follows the Hebrew.

verses.text: Now, LORD God, confirm forever the word that You have spoken concerning Your servant and concerning his house, and do as You have spoken.
verses.comment: 'Confirm forever' is literal.

verses.text: And Your name will be magnified forever, saying, 'The LORD of hosts is God over Israel,' and the house of Your servant David will be established before You.
verses.comment: 'Magnified' is literal translation of Hebrew verb.

verses.text: For You, O LORD of hosts, the God of Israel, have revealed to Your servant, 'I will build you a house.' Therefore Your servant has found courage to pray this prayer to You.
verses.comment: 'Found courage to pray' is literal to the original meaning.

verses.text: Now, O Lord GOD, You are God, and Your words are true, and You have promised this good thing to Your servant.
verses.comment: 'Your words are true' is a literal, theological affirmation.

verses.text: Now therefore, may it please You to bless the house of Your servant, so that it may continue forever before You. For You, O Lord GOD, have spoken, and with Your blessing the house of Your servant will be blessed forever."
verses.comment: 'May it please You to bless' reflects Hebrew; 'continue forever' rendered from Hebrew idiom.
